content.description: Hand-to-fist crack splitting a prominent low buttress about halfway between the Archimedes Cracks and the Knick Knack corridor. North facing and gets shade most of the day.

climbs.name: Soapy Tit Wank
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Nic Conway & Stuart Critchlow, 1993

content.description:
Directly below the start of Lean Two and Hoser is this route.  A dike crosses the rock right to left. It's currently bolted with grey hangers which are possibly the only color which would stand out more than standard silver.

There is a unique move or two on this route that was intriguing.  Give it a try if in the area.
content.protection: Four bolts with grey anchors, smattering of hand size cams for anchor at the base of Hoser.

content.description: This is a pleasant hand and fist crack in a shady location.
content.location: This is near the west end of the north face of Perpetual Motion rock.  It is across from Between A Rock And A Hard Place.

content.description: This route lies on the east wall of a narrow north-south corridor just east of Perpetual Motion.  The corridor cuts through the clump, providing the most direct route between Perpetual Motion and Star Wars Rock.  The north end of the corridor is a short ways west of Hoser on the north side of the clump.  About midway through the corridor, look for a steep finger-eating thin crack across from an overhanging corner (Rainshadow).  Insert your digits and torque your way to the top.  Remember: pain builds character.

An absolutely classic overhanging hand crack.  You'll wish it were three times as long.  Toward the right side of the Perpetual Motion Wall two cracks form a giant "V".  The left crack is Perpetual Motion, the right is Gross Chimney.  A bulging thin hands bit at the start gets the crux out of the way early.  Plug perfect hands (and occasional cams) up the overhanging wall while the pump clock ticks away.  It widens just a bit at the top, but that means you're almost done with it.  The view from the top is awesome, and you probably won't find a line at the base.
content.protection: Cams in the handjam range (2, 2.5, 3), plus something for the anchor up top.

content.description: Intermittent thin crack line on left side of formation. The rock and cracks are pretty grainy, but the movement is pretty cool. Thin fingers to thin hands lead to a reachy crack switch crux and a slab finish. Vogel's old guide grades it at 11a
content.protection: Thin rack, offsets helpful, hands for the anchor
content.location: South east of Between a Rock and A Hard Place. Walk off with a bit of down climbing to the east

content.description: This is a set of twin cracks at the east end of the north side of the Perpetual Motion Clump.  They are best approached by walking east from Star Wars Rock.  The left crack is 5.8, the right crack is 5.10, and if you use them both, it is probably 5.9.
This is a short, steep, clean hand crack in a dihedral.
This is a steep finger crack, with some hand jamming.  It is strenuous and aesthetic, but short.
content.location: There is a corridor about 75 feet northeast of the Perpetual Motion Wall.  Knack is a finger crack on the east wall; Knick is a dihedral on the west wall.

content.description: A thin step-across move (crux) from atop a pointy boulder gains you the thin lieback crack.  Work up that until it peters out, then maneuver left into another crack.  Tricky and tough the whole way--I like it!
content.protection: 1 bolt (needs replaced) and tiny cams; 1 - 2" cams for anchor.
content.location: Approx 15' right of the start to Perpetual Motion (and Gross Chimney), there's a lone bolt (rusty old buttonhead) protecting the opening step-across move.

content.description: This route lies on the north side of the Perpetual Motion Clump, a short distance right (west) of the twin cracks of Lean Two.  It is best approached by heading east from Star Wars Rock.  It follows a right-facing corner up the wall.  The first few ascents forgot to use a rope, most-likely due to an induced chemical imbalance in the brain.  It was a gorgeous day, however, and nobody got hurt.  The corridor approach from Star Wars Rock directly to Perpetual Motion cuts through the clump to the right (west) of this route.
Hollow-sounding flakes make for a spooky lead (my partner backed off, and retrieved our gear after climbing Perpetual Motion).  In addition to being very awkward.
content.location: Same start as Perpetual Motion, but aim slightly right up the slot instead of going left for PM.

content.description:
This slab climb is on a large leaning pillar on the north side of the Perpetual Motion complex of rocks.  Go north through the corridor from Perpetual Motion (past Knick and Knack) and you will come out of the corridor at the base of this route.

The climb follows the right side of the piller, using a blunt arete for a lot of the moves.  Fun climbing - we thought it deserved a star or two.
content.protection: The 1992 guide says this route has 3 bolts, but when we climbed it (2/2003) it had 4 shiny new bolts. Good 2-bolt anchor with rap chains on top.

content.description: A tricky step-up (5.10b) leads to a good hand jam and moderate climbing.  Go left and up along the underside of a large flake, and pass an alcove.  The crux of the climb is just above, as you jam and undercling out over a 6 foot roof.
content.location: This is the next crack system to the left of Perpetual Motion, near the left end of the south face.
